results.title: Underground
results.creator_credit: Pierre Spengler, CiBy 2000, Pandora Films, Novo Film and Emir Kusturica
results.brief_description:
An epic, wild, extremely black tragi-comedy, ‘Underground’ traces the war torn history of Yugoslavia from World War II to Bosnia. The story focuses on two friends, Marco and Blacky, and their absurd misadventures over the fifty years. The characters in this film inhabit a world of self-delusion, deceit and abuse, but also of revelry, vitality and love. Kusturica’s blend of lush surrealism, wistful fantasy and dark irony, perfectly juxtapose both the hilarity and intense drama of this tale of townsfolk who, in an effort to escape the brutality of war go underground. It is both an historical documentation of the complexities of Yugoslavian politics, as well as an absurdly dark fairytale of unpredictable proportions about the absurdity of war.

Credits: Producer, Pierre Spengler ; director, Emir Kusturica ; writer, Dusan Kovacevic ; photography, Vilko Filac ; music, Goran Bregovic ; editing, Branka Ceperac.
Cast: Miki Manojlovic, Lazar Ristovski, Slavko Stimac, Srdjan Todorovic, Pierre Spengler, Branko Cvejic.

results.title: Love serenade
results.creator_credit: Jan Chapman, Mandy Walker, Shirley Barrett, AFFC and Saddleback Productions
results.brief_description:
Two bored sisters, Dimity and Vicki-Ann, live in the small country town of Sunray. Their new neighbour, a brooding self-centered type, formerly star D.J. of a drive-time programme on Brisbane radio, threatens to turn the sisters’ world upside down. Dimity and Vicki-Ann find themselves in competition for his affections as each develops a severe crush on the aging Lothario with a predilection for 70’s music and young women. Awards: Cannes International Film Festival 1996: Camera d’Or for Shirley Barrett. Also available on VHS.

Credits: Producer, Jan Chapman ; director, writer, Shirley Barrett ; photography, Mandy Walker.
Cast: Miranda Otto, Rebecca Frith, George Shevtsov, John Alansu.

results.title: The Jungle book (plus special effects production)
results.creator_credit: Zoltan Korda, Alexander Korda and United Artists Corporation
results.brief_description: A young boy returns to his native village attempting to adapt to human customs and his adopted family. The discovery of a coin in the jungle awakens the greed of the village people who hope to discover a legendary buried treasure. Disillusioned by the greed and violence of humanity he retreats to his loyal and trusted friends … the beasts of the jungle. Stars Sabu. Based on Rudyard Kipling’s “Jungle book”. This version includes special effects techniques and production outtakes.

results.title: Kansas City
results.creator_credit: CiBy 2000, Sandcastle Productions and Robert Altman
results.brief_description:
Set in 1934 at the height of the Depression, ‘Kansas City’ examines the intricate and often violent undercurrents that have governed American society, and in particular its race relations. Jennifer Jason Leigh plays Blondie, a working class telegraphist who wants to save her boyfriend Johnny (Dermot Mulroney) from the murderous plans of jazz club owner Seldom Seen (Harry Belafonte). Blondie kidnaps the rich Carolyn (Miranda Richardson), hoping that Carolyn’s politician husband will help save the unlucky Johnny. But it is election eve and in a city dominated by warring prohibition-era gangster tribes, Blondie finds that her needs are never a priority. Though Altman seamlessly weaves elements of noir, screwball comedy and the crime genre, it is his love of jazz music that informs this film. He organised some of the world’s leading contemporary jazz musicians to inhabit such roles as Lester Young and Coleman Hawkins (and young actor Albert J. Burnes plays a 14 year old Charlie Parker who is obsessed by the jazz clubs in the city). It is the dynamic score which propels the narrative of the film and Altman’s mise-en-scene is itself “scored” to the performances of the musicians. Kansas City was one of the leading jazz centres in the United States of America and this film is an homage to that history. But as always, Altman reveals both an intricate knowledge of cinema and a profound knowledge of the American history.

Credits: Producer, director, Robert Altman ; writer, Robert Altman, Frank Barhydt ; photography, Oliver Stapleton ; music, Hal Willner ; editing, Geraldine Peroni.
Cast: Jennifer Jason Leigh, Miranda Richardson, Harry Belafonte, Michael Murphy, Dermot Mulroney, Steve Buscemi.

results.title: Secrets and lies
results.creator_credit: Simon Channing-Williams, CiBy 2000, Thin Man Films, Channel 4 Films and Mike Leigh
results.brief_description:
Cynthia is an unmarried factory worker who lives in a state of siege with her perpetually enraged daughter, Roxanne. In sharp contrast, Cynthia’s brother, Maurice, runs a thriving photographic studio and works hard to provide a luxury home for his neurotic, childless wife. Meanwhile, an adopted young black woman, Hortense, is scouring London for her real mother, who, she learns to her shock, is white. An acutely accurate portrait of familial tensions, which reflects Leigh’s practice of carrying out months of intensive workshopping with his actors before beginning to shoot. The film remains true to its subjects even as the story veers from comedy to tragedy. Also available on 16mm.

Credits: Producer, Simon Channing-Williams ; director, writer, Mike Leigh ; photography, Dick Pope ; music, Andrew Dickson.
Cast: Timothy Spall, Brenda Blethyn, Phyllis Logan, Marianne Jean-Baptiste, Claire Rushbrook, Rin Cook, Lesley Manville, Elizabeth Berrington, Michelle Austin, Lee Ross, Emma Amos, Hannah Davis.

results.title: Spanking the monkey
results.creator_credit: David O. Russell, Dean Silvers and Buckeye Films
results.brief_description:
This black comedy was an indie hit for director/writer David O. Russell, with the content of the narrative, and the title of the film (a non-de-plum for masturbation) causing a minor furore. Ray, an introverted student studying to be a surgeon, returns home for what he intends to be a brief stay prior to taking up an internship. Upon his arrival however his controlling father presses him into caring for his physically compromised and emotionally depressed mother. As Ray assists his mother with her recuperation, their bond becomes incestuous in tone and increasingly bizarre. With an eye for the absurd and a heavy tilt toward black comedy, this film’s Oedipal overtone encourages uncomfortable audience participation in what is a rarely explored subject matter. The pathos of the screenplay manages to outweigh the mere shock value of the topics explored, and the film genuinely engages on an emotional level with an unusual coming of age story.

Credits: Producer, Dean Silvers ; director, writer, David O. Russell ; photography, Michael Mayers ; music, Mark Sandman ; editing, Pamela Martin.
Cast: Jeremy Davies, Elizabeth Newett, Benjamin Hendrickson, Alberta Watson, Carla Gallo.

results.title: Career girls
results.creator_credit: Simon Channing-Williams, Channel Four Television, Thin Man Films, Matrix Films and Mike Leigh
results.brief_description:
Meeting at King’s Cross rail station one day, ex student housemates and friends Hannah and Annie, are reunited after six years apart for a weekend o apart. Annie, initially a painfully shy young woman with a noticeablef reminiscences. Initially hesitant around one another, as time progresses we are privy to their insecurities, loves and animosities, both past and present, that they shared together and skin condition has gained confidence as she has grown older. Hannah still has a quick tongue and will do anything to avoid the ‘psychobabble’ inflicted on her by people who attempt to understand her. Throughout the weekend they meet people who remind them of the events that have shaped their lives, awakening them to the realisation of where they’ve come from, and where they are headed.

Credits: Producer, Simon Channing-Williams ; director, writer, Mike Leigh ; photography, Dick Pope ; music, Marianne Jean-Baptiste ; editing Robin Sales.
Cast: Katrin Cartlidge, Lynda Steadman, Mark Benton, Kate Byers, Andy Serkis.

results.title: The End of violence
results.creator_credit: Wim Wenders, Nicholas Klein, Deepak Nayar, Kintop Pictures, Road Movies Filmproduktion and CiBy 2000
results.brief_description:
A film about conspiracy, the effects of violence in our culture, and personal transformation. Mike Max is a leading Hollywood producer, whose triumph has come from a string of extremely violent action films. His work is his life, and he neglects his wife in his pursuit of success. Frustrated with his lack of attention, she leaves him, and Max is forced to admit he was a less-than supportive husband. Not long after, he becomes involved in a violent killing, and fearing for his life, goes into hiding, falling victim to a new top-secret surveillance system that caught the crime on camera. Escaping into L.A.’s underworld, Max confronts violence more terrifying than anything he could put on film.

Credits: Producers, Deepak Nayer, Nicholas Klein ; director, Wim Wenders ; writer, Nicholas Klein ; photography, Pascal Rabaud ; music, Ry Cooder ; editing, Peter Pryzygodda.
Cast: Bill Pullman, Andie MacDowell, Traci Lind, Rosalind Chao, K. Todd Freeman, Gabriel Byrne.

results.title: The Times of Harvey Milk
results.creator_credit: Robert Epstein, Richard Schmiechen, Harvey Milk Film Project and Black Sand Productions
results.brief_description:
An exceptionally moving documentary about Harvey Milk, the first openly gay candidate elected to San Francisco’s Board of Supervisors. A courageous activist, Milk worked hard to express the political concerns of not only gays and lesbians, but also of African-Americans, Hispanics and other so- called American minorities. After eleven months in office, Milk and the Mayor of San Francisco were assassinated by Dan White, a conservative member of the Board of Supervisors. The subsequent trial, in which White received a lenient sentence, resulted in massive rioting in San Francisco by gay and lesbian activists. Amidst the tragedy the film builds a convincing and impassioned picture of a man committed to human rights and human dignity. Academy Award winner for best documentary, 1985.

Credits: Producer, Richard Schmiechen ; director, Robert Epstein ; writer, Judith Coburn, Carter Wilson ; photography, Doug Dunderdale, Nancy Morita, Thomas O’Shea ; music, Mark Isham ; editor, Deborah Hoffmann, Robert Epstein.
Cast: Harvey Fierstein (narrator).

results.description:
An exceptionally moving documentary about Harvey Milk, the first openly gay candidate elected to San Francisco’s Board of Supervisors. A courageous activist, Milk worked hard to express the political concerns of not only gays and lesbians, but also of African-Americans, Hispanics and other so- called American minorities. After eleven months in office, Milk and the Mayor of San Francisco were assassinated by Dan White, a conservative member of the Board of Supervisors. The subsequent trial, in which White received a lenient sentence, resulted in massive rioting in San Francisco by gay and lesbian activists. Amidst the tragedy the film builds a convincing and impassioned picture of a man committed to human rights and human dignity. Academy Award winner for best documentary, 1985.

Credits: Producer, Richard Schmiechen ; director, Robert Epstein ; writer, Judith Coburn, Carter Wilson ; photography, Doug Dunderdale, Nancy Morita, Thomas O’Shea ; music, Mark Isham ; editor, Deborah Hoffmann, Robert Epstein.
Cast: Harvey Fierstein (narrator).
